title: Will there be an initial public offering on either the Shanghai Stock Exchange or the Shenzhen Stock Exchange before 1 January 2016?
preds:
Looks like this should close today...
"China’s stocks fell for the first time in five days, with the Shanghai Composite Index retreating 1.7 percent as initial public offerings resumed after a five-month freeze. "
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-03/asian-futures-signal-more-stock-losses-on-draghi-disappointment and here...
http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2015-11/30/content_22529946.htm

Four more on Shenzhen:
1. Shenzhen Silver Basis Technology Co.
2. Xiamen Wanli Stone Stock Co.
3. Shenzhen Click Technology Co.
4. Shenzhen Qixin Construction Group Co
http://www.szse.cn/szseWeb/FrontController.szse?ACTIONID=7&AJAX=AJAX-TRUE&CATALOGID=1845&TABKEY=tab2 Here's a document which provides a brief overview of the IPO process for Shenzhen. Along the lines we've been discussing, the IPO process ends, from reading this document, at the "listing" stage. This reminds me now of the impeachment procedure discussion lol! The impeachment procedure subsumes impeachment. The IPO process subsumes IPOs. LOL. The procedure/process and the underlying event are not the same. It's like saying the birthing process is not complete until a birth certificate is issued. Tell that to the parents and baby. No, that's not quite right. Rather, it's like saying the birth has not occurred until the birth certificate is obtained.
http://www.legalink.ch/Root/Sites/legalink/Resources/Questionnaires/IPOs/Asia/Legalink%20IPO_China.pdf Here's a decent perspective, which sounds more accurate to me: "Once the issuer completes the offering of shares, it may apply to the stock exchange for the listing of new shares." Now that's right. The offering and listing are independent.
(From: Chinese Capital Market Takeover and Restructuring Guide  By Chengwei Liu - page 336)
https://books.google.com/books?id=N8Gf_bdA0zcC&pg=PA336&lpg=PA336&dq=shenzhen+ipo+subscription+listing&source=bl&ots=sgEoYuq7Ps&sig=N8SvInQsRAuCpbr3f6Tk3iuO1IU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYvITowMHJAhUGQCYKHVGjCsIQ6AEINDAE#v=onepage&q=shenzhen%20ipo%20subscription%20listing&f=false
Even in this book, though, the author conflates the "procedures of offering" (e.g., refunds of excess subscription fees, etc.) with the offering itself, to arrive at a "completed offering." So, in any case, it's not the listing stage that is holding this Q up; or it shouldn't be. Which returns us to the notion that a company that experiences a suspended. withdrawn, or reversed IPO (after a definite announcement of a subscription offer) cannot ever have another "IPO." Hmm. I passed a quick evaluation of that already, but I'll think this over some more later. Is it more like lost-virginity, or re-doing third down after a penalty? In the latter case it's again called third down.

China securities regulator says another 10 companies ready for IPOs (+?)
http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/12/04/us-china-ipo-idUKKBN0TN02O20151204

http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/singapore/china-based-bhg-retail/2315844.html
From link: BHG Retail Trust Management has launched an initial public offering (IPO) of units in BHG Retail REIT (real estate investment trust) at an offering price of S$0.80 per unit, ....This will make it the first listing on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) this year. The final prospectus of the IPO was filed with the Monetary Authority of Singapore on Wednesday.

"Hubei Kailong Chemical Group Co. and other companies offered IPO shares earlier this week"
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-03/china-stock-index-futures-climb-after-biggest-gain-in-a-month

WSJ: "The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) allowed initial public offerings to resume this week on the country’s two stock exchanges after a five-month freeze."

“25 of the 28 companies meant to be listed before year-end have hired auditing or law firms with senior executives who sit on the Commission’s screening committee.”
http://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-rigged-ipos-1449102648
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-01/china-s-central-bank-steps-up-cash-injections-amid-ipo-restart : Increased liquidity to support IPO restart. Correction to estimate:  Prior error

according to xinhua the q should be closed........ per #redacted https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/50556. If xinhua not believed then reuters? http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/27/china-bonds-idUSL3N13M2LN20151127#tG7F8LKMhKxSRhrD.97 "Initial public offers in the stock market resumed after Nov. 20, with 10 out of 28 companies that previously delayed their offers during the recent market turmoil launching this week 
Read more at Reutershttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/27/china-bonds-idUSL3N13M2LN20151127#oxOOjdjL7TSZUsjI.99". Not sure why this is not announced as closed, but not sure of lots of things
Stocks stabilizing today. Will keep a daily watch, as companies do not launch IPOs during instability. http://www.bloomberg.com/quote/SHCOMP:IND

From: http://www.shanghaidaily.com/business/finance/Shares-drop-ahead-of-IPOs-next-week/shdaily.shtml:
.........a batch of initial public offerings next week........Ten companies will start their IPO subscriptions next week, which is expected to freeze around 1 trillion yuan (US$156 billion) in funds, analysts said. IFP asks about an "initial public offering", Shanghai Dailey reports "initial public offerings next week".  Looks like a match.

China Explosives Maker Prices IPO as Share Sales Resume
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-27/china-explosives-maker-prices-ipo-as-share-sales-resume While I have no understanding as to the technical term "online subscription date," this would appear to me to fulfill the common sense definition of "an offer;" which is able to be responded to on November 30. (*Please* let us not devolve into what the various elements of a contract are, or on the ability of a party to perform such element(s), or the timing of an "acceptance;" an offer has been made.)
http://www.szse.cn/szseWeb/FrontController.szse?ACTIONID=7&AJAX=AJAX-TRUE&CATALOGID=1845&TABKEY=tab2 [Edit: China Resumes IPOs: http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-11/30/c_134868871.htm ]

Dropping probability by 25% and watching closely to see whether this is an anomaly or beginning of a rout. Down 5.48% so far today. Dateline 11-27-15 Holger Zschaepitz ‏@Schuldensuehner
Good morning from Berlin. Black Friday in #China w/ Shanghai Comp drops >5%.

Better late than never: At what point is an IPO considered to be "on the market" (for this IFP)?  When traded freely on the given stock market after listing? or when the shares become available for bid or purchase?

http://www.shanghaidaily.com/business/finance/Pending-IPOs-take-the-wind-out-of-shares/shdaily.shtml " . . . 10 companies will start their IPO subscriptions between next Monday and December 2, with an equal number headed for the Shanghai Stock Exchange and the Shenzhen bourse. This [is the] first batch of listings after China’s securities regulator lifted a four-month ban on IPOs . . .

The China Securities Regulatory Commission has restarted IPOs for five companies to list on the Shanghai stock exchange and five in Shenzhen, according to a statement on its official microblog. 
~~~~~~~~~

~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  " . . . resumption next week of IPOs. . . "

(No change in forecast) Nov 20: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-20/china-restarts-ipo-process-for-10-companies-as-stocks-stabilize China’s securities regulator gave the green light to initial public offerings by 10 companies as a five-month freeze on new share sales ends. The China Securities Regulatory Commission has restarted IPOs for five companies to list on the Shanghai stock exchange and five in Shenzhen, according to a statement on its official microblog. The 10 companies had already received approval before IPOs were halted in July to prop up the stock market amid a $5 trillion rout. ~~~

From the link
China’s securities watchdog said last week it will allow 28 IPOs by year-end and let the market to play a bigger role in the supply and pricing of new listings.
An uptick in U.S. inflation, released Tuesday, is the latest signal supporting expectations that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates next month. http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nikkei-rises-on-weaker-yen-other-markets-struggle-2015-11-18

Among the 28 IPOs that were suspended in July because of sharp market falls, ten companies were given the approval to restart their initial public offerings (IPO) Friday, according to Deng Ge, spokesman with the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC). Among the ten companies, five will be listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, including Anji Foodstuff Co., Banbao Co., Suzhou Douson Drilling & Production Equipment Co., Readers Publishing & Media Co. and Bomin Electronics Co. Three will be listed on the Small and Medium-sized Enterprise Board (SME) of the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, including Hubei Kailong Chemical Group Co., Beijing Sanfo Outdoor Products Co. and Zhejiang Zhongjian Technology Co. And the rest two will be listed on the ChiNext-board of the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, including Shanghai Fortune Techgroup Co. and Thunder Software Technology Co.
http://en.xinfinance.com/html/Industries/Finance/2015/168077.shtml

http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nikkei-rises-on-weaker-yen-other-markets-struggle-2015-11-18 " . . .  investors anticipate that officials could announce as soon as Friday plans to relaunch mainland listings, which were halted during the summer selloff. . . . China’s securities watchdog said last week it will allow 28 IPOs by year-end

The Bloomberg link below from yesterday sats the Bank of China has injected liquidity into the system in preparation for anticipated IPO's.  They neglected to do this the last time and apparently gummed up the works. If the BOC is getting ready, does that mean an IPO is imminent?  Seems like they are doing this with SOME inside knowledge...maybe? http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-19/pboc-doubles-reverse-repos-to-inject-funds-before-ipos-resume

A third regulatory official involved in China’s initial public offerings has been arrested
http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1a6146dc-8e82-11e5-8be4-3506bf20cc2b.html It seems @shanghaitrader was right all along. I wonder if these same officials rushed out the decision to lift the IPO ban as perhaps some last minute attempt to maintain position. If you slice off the top three decision-makers in a regulatory program such as Chinese IPOs, I wouldn't expect that there could be but only one or two left, at most, that have any real policy knowledge and operational understanding of the process. Will the recent lifting of the ban be rescinded if the motivation for it is found to have been political preservation rather than economic?
"China Shares Fall as Chances of IPO Flurry Nears"  [1] [1] http://www.wsj.com/articles/japan-shares-rise-on-weak-yen-1447810897

One suspects that the gummint would like at least a couple of IPOs in order to show that faith has been restored; appearances are quite important to the Party (luckily this is not true anywhere else...).  The IPOs don't have to be successful to be counted, I don't suppose. They could even be withdrawn, although I'll bet the gummint would stump up some cash rather than permit this.

Ugh - now I'm doubting my own analysis. I still wonder who the buyers will be, though I guess it could be the government. They have seem to want to normalize markets and provide funding to these companies. A successful IPO would provide the confidence that they want the market to have.

Upping this since I just read the lifting of the ban. Doesn't negate the fact that IPO's usually don't happen during a market adjustment like this. While the companies need financing, market conditions would usually make it too unattractive to do so. China's not a normal market though and anyway, how should one think about "equity" and ownership in companies of a communist country. A shareholder doesn't "own" a share of the company in any real sense of the word.
IPO's are rare when markets crash, though it has recovered somewhat. It could happen, but risk appetite is still low there, I think.
Thanks to Xu, I'll jump in strong:) Thanks for the link!!
You have about a week to get on board; this has to happen.  Moved from 91% (when it was lonely) to 98% where is now crowded.
Per Xu, I guess so. I would be at 90-95% to account for the possiblity of delay, but I've been pretty low in this already, so up it goes.

Jumping in at 100% thanks to the link from Xu --> http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/42768 Specifically, the following paragraph: "Ten of the 28 companies that were in the process of listing when the freeze began will restart the process after Nov. 20, said another CSRC official at the same briefing, who asked not to be identified because of agency rules. It will take two weeks for the 10 to complete the process, while the remaining 18 will sell shares by the end of the year, Deng said."  ~~~ COMMENT: Two weeks after Nov. 20th is (before) Jan 1st, so this seems like a slam dunk. However, there's always a chance that something might complicate matters, but given that there doesn't seem to be anything like that (at this point), it seems relatively safe to jump in at 100% and then keep an eye on things.

Only just saw the news for this even though it happened a week ago. And its not really an active question here either. 
"Ten of the 28 companies that were in the process of listing when the freeze began will restart the process after Nov. 20, said another CSRC official at the same briefing, who asked not to be identified because of agency rules. It will take two weeks for the 10 to complete the process, while the remaining 18 will sell shares by the end of the year, Deng said."
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-09/china-to-resume-ipos-by-year-end-as-stocks-enter-bull-market
This question should be closing around the beginning of December then.

China's IPO chief under investigation
http://www.financeasia.com/News/403885,chinas-ipo-chief-under-investigation.aspx Not sure if this could derail the current batch of in-process IPOs or not. Assuming not; but they have an excuse now to reverse course if they wish. (-1 on that risk.)
http://www.shanghaidaily.com/business/finance/Sale-of-15-IPO-stake-soon/shdaily.shtml Report of a 15% of PSBC IPO to international investors - "soon".
Forgot to account for the lifting of the embargo.  That makes it kind of likely.

The CSRC has removed its embargo on IPO, which paves the way for listings.  However, they will still need to go through the approval process. It is likely that at least some will list prior to Chinese New Year, but that doesn't imply it would be before our New Year.  Many companies will have been on track to IPO though, so lead time for IPOing this companies may be short.

http://www.businessinsider.com/china-is-about-to-unleash-the-same-policy-that-blew-up-the-stock-market-2015-11 They've just permitted IPOs again. Good chance it will happen soon. This one fell off the radar a bit.

http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-11/09/c_134798597.htm The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) said on Friday that IPOs will be restarted with 28 companies allowed to go public before the end of this year.

This looks like it is going to happen.  Interesting move by the central committee, but will likely be supported in the shadows with the government buying up shares to make them successful and continue the illusion that is China.

The CSRC further detailed that 10 of the 28 firms that were granted with regulatory approval for new share sales are set to launch their respective IPOs after Nov. 20.

http://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/article_xinhua.aspx?id=308322
Shanghai Daily expectation is before year end.
Forecast per the Nov. 20 date, and assuming the year end reference is not the Chinese New Year.

I was way wrong on this one! http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/us-china-ipo-idUSKCN0SV1AK20151106 "China's securities regulator said on Friday it would allow the resumption of initial public offerings in China, lifting a suspension put into effect in July as regulators desperately tried to slow a devastating stock market crash.... The CSRC said that 28 companies which had seen their already-approved listings halted by the freeze would be the first out of the gate, adding they have two weeks to prepare for the resumption, with the first batch of 10 companies launching after November 20. The announcement comes after signs Chinese stock markets have finally stabilized after a rocky summer; this week the CSI300 index .CSI300 posted its best weekly performance since June. Mainland stock indexes are up by more than 20 percent from the bottom of a crash struck in August, technically marking a return to a bull market." No time to postmortem now but will have to look at how I screwed this one up later.
http://www.wsj.com/articles/china-to-lift-ban-on-ipos-1446804114 On top of implementing the release slowly, market could always re-tank in next couple weeks.  Unlikely, however

Increasing odds after reports the government will lift sanctions: https://www.gjopen.com/questions/4-will-there-be-an-initial-public-offering-on-either-the-shanghai-stock-exchange-or-the-shenzhen-stock-exchange-before-1-january-2016

Following Austerity. http://www.businessspectator.com.au/news/2015/11/6/china/china-lift-4-month-ipo-ban The Reuters article is very specific, mentioning 20 November as the launch date. However, the above report is a little less confident. "China to lift 4-month IPO ban
DOW JONES NEWSWIRES  1 HOUR AGO  
DATAROOM EQUITY CAPITAL MARKETS ECONOMY CHINA
China will lift a four-month ban on new stock listings after it "improves" relevant policies, the official Xinhua News Agency reported on Friday, citing the country's securities regulator. The announcement came amid signs of a notable recovery in investor confidence and after the Shanghai stock market rallied more than 8 per cent in the past three days.  While Xinhua offered no further details, local media such as the Caixin Magazine cited a spokesman from the China Securities Regulatory Commission as saying that 28 approved but suspended IPOs would materialise by the end of the year. Ten out of the 28 companies could complete new share sales in about two weeks, said Caixin, quoting the spokesman.  China imposed its ban on IPOs in early July after the country's stock market lost more than 40 per cent in a massive rout, which halted listing plans for nearly 600 firms.

Reuters updated:
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/china-ipo-idUSL3N1313NV20151106
"The CSRC said that 28 companies which had seen their already-approved listings halted by the freeze would be the first out of the gate, adding they have two weeks to prepare for the resumption, with the first batch of 10 companies launching after November 20."

http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/china-ipo-idUSL3N1313NV20151106
China's securities regulator said on Friday it would allow the resumption of initial public offerings in China, lifting a suspension put into effect in July as regulators desperately tried to slow a devastating stock market crash.
...
The CSRC said that 28 companies which had seen their already-approved listings halted by the freeze would be the first out of the gate, adding they have two weeks to prepare for the resumption.
The announcement comes after signs Chinese stock markets have finally stabilised; this week the CSI300 index posted its best weekly performance since June with rising transaction volumes.

"The IPO suspension will end, as it has each time the government has imposed such a moratorium, although if precedent is anything to go by the last time the government intervened to suspend IPOs was in November 2012; the ban lasted 14 months and was never properly explained by the regulator. The shortest suspension lasted three months in 2001."  [1] [1] http://www.financeasia.com/News/403147,renaissance-bets-on-restart-of-take-private-trend.aspx

SSEA @ 3622
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-16/china-analysts-see-ipo-resumption-by-year-end-as-stocks-recover
August article estimated IPO's would resume with SSEA around 4500, as brokers pledged not to sell holdings below that level. Not sure if this info is still accurate.
Investigation of CSRC is still ongoing following stock market crash earlier this year.
Following shanghaitrader, and noting that the timeframe is getting short.

Ratcheting this down further.  The Chinese government has picked up its purging of the investment community domestically and I think that places a greater tilt to this question.  When you examine those that have been purged, it has been the risk takers and that does not bode well for things like IPOs this year.
As before, shanghaitrader should know ... -1. (What a killjoy you are!)

the central anti-corruption bureau has started an onsite check-up at the Chinese SEC, and this recent operation involves a dozen of other institutions, too, including the PBOC and Chinese Forex Bureau. According to the news, the inspection teams will stay for two months in these institutions. Within the two months, I susptect all the staff in Chinese SEC would be busy digging out/sorting their archieves, deleting their phone messages and call list, answering all sorts of  questions, and writing lengthy detailed reports for pretty much everything. This has the same effect of putting them on holiday for two months, because nobody would be really working on anything, So, I think the chance of a change of policy is zero now.

"Chinese investors [hold] $22 trillion of investable assets"
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-30/hong-kong-bourse-wants-to-expand-shanghai-link-to-ipos-li-says
"China’s CICC Prices Hong Kong IPO at Top of Range" (HK exchange, but still a good signal. +1)
http://www.wsj.com/articles/chinas-cicc-prices-hong-kong-ipo-at-top-of-range-1446290476

I continue to think China will allow an IPO this year to match Xi's message of free markets, even if this message has been plagued with some contradictions. After all, the yuan is being seriously considered as a second global reserve currency.
A company which has to IPO will IPO.

Foxconn to list IPO on Chinese exchange! 
[... within three to five years.]
http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news/content?id=20150628000003&cid=1206
Too late in the year to offer an IPO. Till markets don't stabilise for a period of at least 6 months it will not happen
Suspended, but it will be difficult to stop the flow for long.

The strength of other markets to publicly raise money makes Chinese markets less attractive because there is a lack of trust against Chinese government by the public (even its own people). China needs a littlev more time to prove itself and win the market's trust before an IPO launch.
These exchanges see themselves as separate and unique, thus will act on market info unrelated to the us or European markets.

Going from 12->10%. Chinese easing announced yesterday...RRR decline and rate cut in tandem...reinforce that Chinese govt still quite concerned about weakness in economy, and growth below its internal targets. From the government's perspective, IPOs are only permissible during more economically stable times. IPO window will reopen when Chinese economy declines at a rate the govt is comfortable with.

-2 on planned reverse IPO.
"We've been planning this for many years" said an executive.
Why do I not believe him?
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/23/china-logistics-idUSL3N12N24K20151023

One of the main purposes of the gov trying to prop up the market a year ago was to create enough enthusiasm so that the naive public would rush in and provide capital for all the toxi garbage of state owned banks and corporations - most of which were on the top of the approved IPO list. Now with the initiation of new Chinese version of QE, most banks and hence state owned companies don't have an urgent need to suck capital from the equity market anymore.  And hence, I decrease my forecast to 5%. Rationale for previous forecare of 15%: the mkt plunges every time after the IPO suspention was lifted, so the politically correct decision for the Chinese SEC to make is to not further ruin the vunerable mkt, which is currently far from having stablized/bottomed. the reason i assign a probability higher than 10% is that there's been increasing political instability in China this year, and the major government departments have started making obviously stupid decisions, which beneath the surface is to benifit certain interest groups who are in for a short-term profit. Even the official stock market rescue was recently reported to have been completely taken advantage of by front-running and insider trading. so I wouldn't be too surprised to learn that those big firms with huge/collapsing debt burden bribed the Chinese SEC enough that the SEC decided to re-initiate IPOs, disregarding the general market sentiment, the risk of losing office, and the sure outcome of being blamed by the media.
Prediction based on historical IPO suspension

Chinese public continues to be excluded from privatization of public assets
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/18/bank-of-china-ipo-idUSL3N12I05220151018 I'm beginning to wonder if the plumbs were held-out intentionally ... -2

"shares of companies that went public with disappointing IPO prices in September are currently providing positive returns"
http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/data-years-biggest-ipo-prices-estimates-34495304 That's it. If you can restrain the greed, you can float a fair IPO, and have a true win-win. I was way too optimistic ... from 25 to 23%

From 30 to 25%
"When one state-backed Chinese company invests in another, getting the best available return on investment may not be the only consideration."
There are still so many assets to privatize, but it's such a mess.
http://blogs.reuters.com/breakingviews/2015/10/15/hong-kong-ipos-leaning-too-heavily-on-cornerstones/

I was staying away from this one for quite awhile because I don't see any economic reason for a company to list, but the political situation could have a strong impact on this.  Oddly enough, there is a small article today in the Wall Street Journal about a Chinese company that makes sex toys looking to list.  This could be a great trial balloon for the Chinese market with a company that is not likely to raise a great deal either way and would not be seen as an indicator of anything bad if it didn't go well.  No timeframes were given, but giving this even odds to happen at this point.
http://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2015/10/14/the-next-hot-chinese-listing-a-sex-toy-maker/
It seems that most of the crowd is leaning on the opinions of a few.  I'm growing uncomfortable with such a strong forecast on an issue I don't understand, so I'm moving from the crowd to 35%

If their markets were stable right now, I believe we would see a number of public offerings. However, I believe China will be happy just to have their markets stable for a few months. Wait until the first or second quarter of next year to see a flurry of IPOs

Reducing 15 to 12%. Time running out. Economic numbers still bad. China could care less about foreign opinions to "restore confidence", which are touted by the higher-probability guessers below. China cares about stabilizing the market. IPOs are seen as sucking liquidity out of the market. They're permitted when the market is strong, not weak.

Escalating tensions in China's financial system
"Hebei Financing defaulted on us, and we defaulted on our clients"
http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/banking-finance/chinese-investor-stabs-asset-management-ceo-after-default
from 52 to 32%
I don't believe so. Although that would signal to the world China's markets are now stable, since they aren't I don't believe China wants more egg on their face
China is trying to restore confidence in its markets after the massive interventions in late summer. So I think they will permit IPOs before year-end.

Markets have recovered though regulators are likely to remain cagey. Also, looks like people are just listing in Hong Kong.

Given the depressed state of the markets plus high volatility it's hard to see the IPO freeze being lifted in the immediate future. In addition the question is "Will there be an initial public offering" and not "Will the initial public offering freeze be lifted" so the IPO would have to actually take place by 1 January so the clock is running down very quickly.
Economic situation inside occupied China far worse than the dictatorship is letting on.

It is important to realize that the question isn't: "Will the IPO suspension be lift?"  This is important b/c since the suspension, the market is down BIG, which means that far fewer companies will actually want to IPO right now.  Also, w/ 3 months remaining till this question time runs out, there will be a delay between the time the ban is lifted and when the IPO actually launches trading.  I've never been an i-banker, but just as a rough estimate given my limited research time available, I figure it'd take around a month from the time a ban is lifted to the time when the first IPO is actually launched.  So I'm realistically asking if the ban will be lifted in the next 2 months.  China likes to exert control, and I think they really think their logically control can get the markets to do what they want--look at their behavior w/r/t the renminbi.  So I think they dont lift the ban in the next two months b/c the markets are still in the doldrums. On the flipside, as I write this, the H-share market is showing small signs of life (while the A-share market remains closed for a week).

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/10/world/asia/in-china-a-forceful-crackdown-in-response-to-stock-market-crisis.html?emc=edit_th_20150910&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 Sept 9. "The Communist Party’s response to China’s monthslong stock market crisis has been swift and forceful. In addition to spending as much as $235 billion to buy shares and bolster prices, the authorities have imposed a range of extraordinary restrictions on the sale of stocks — and backed them with the full weight of a security apparatus usually more focused on political dissent than equity trades." "After decades of watching China make slow but steady progress in building Western-style financial markets, many are now asking whether the party is reversing course — . . ." "The authorities are canvassing industry players in several cities, including Beijing and Shanghai. Police officers under the Chinese Ministry of Public Security specializing in economic crimes have joined agents from the nation’s securities regulator on inspections of investment funds and brokerage firms. The authorities are combing records and questioning transactions that appear to profit from or contribute to a falling market, according to employees of investment firms who, like others who spoke anonymously, said they feared reprisals." " . . . the Chinese authorities have been vague about what kinds of transactions have been prohibited and for how long. The police have said they are investigating “malicious” short-selling but have not said what that entails." "The government has also suspended initial public offerings and prohibited investors who own more than 5 percent of a company from selling shares." "Censors have ordered the Chinese news media to avoid any reporting that might result in a market sell-off. With the economy growing at its slowest pace in a quarter-century and the party leadership worried about social unrest, discussion of the markets can draw official scrutiny almost as quickly as political speech."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  It sounds like the Chinese authorities are trying everything.  mparrault says that the last IPO freeze lasted 15 months and this one just began in July, so lifting it before New Year's would mean less than 6 months.  I only know what I read, so my forecast is conservative.
No end to market turmoil for now. 6 months is fairly short compared to previous IPO halts.
China suspended initial public offerings, in an effort to shore up its stock market, which has had the largest three-week drop since 1992.

Suspension has been in place since July, so it is likely to continue for awhile--at least until the current crisis has been mitigated. On the other hand, these things seldom go one for a really long time.

sve je stvar politike a ne ekonomije     
everything is a matter of politics, not economics

Stabilization is the main concern for the Chinese government especially when they've lost some credibility for their handling of the previous market turmoil. I don't think the Chinese government is ready to let the market go loose in the short term especially given recent signals that tighten control of the stock market, such as limiting the hedging ability by putting a ceiling of 100 futures contracts per market participant.
Markets appear to have stabilized after a summer of selling. A new IPO would be a bullish sign for global markets and Chinese investors-- something that has been in short supply of late
Apply logistic regression followed by Ausrücken operator.
Given recent volatility and falling confidence in the market and economy, the short timeline on this question makes it odds against finding in favor of this proposition.

China unlikely to want to increase supply of shares at present, in order to prevent dilution to stock market returns, and also to avoid introducing extra event risk (regulatory). If Fed were to raise funds rate materially (25bps) that could argue in favour of a need to compete for capital with more issuance. But prices in US, as measured by realtime trackers, are rolling over, and in current volatility a 15bp or no raise seems more likely.  Even if China does reapprove IPO's, one has to get to market in this timeframe, despite inevitably higher regulatory scrutiny levels.

Yes, "More Info" links indicate the primary reason for discontinuing the IPO's is to prevent them from diverting new funds from existing stock issues (one effort intended to prop up the falling prices).  Although the links do not specificly identify a government mandate, 28 IPO's were suspended: 18 on Shenzen and 10 on Shanghi. The slowing Chinese economy has resulted in capital outflows, pushing down the currency  The upcoming FED decision to raise rates, if further delayed per World Bank and IMF advise, may help to stabilize the Chinese markets.  If the FED does postpone the rate hike, I suspect the resumption of suspended IPO's could happen fairly soon.

It's believed Beijing has targeted Shanghai reaching 4500 as the stability trigger for IPOs. It's no where near this. 3155.04 as of a few days ago.
